section.title: Accessing fields of the heap object
section.p: Properties of heap objects are accessed using a simple dot notation:

An alias can be defined in the FROM Clause to identify the current object, i.e. row in the SQL analogy, on which the OQL statement operates. Without alias, the field is assumed to be one of the fields of the current object. Fields are attributes of the Java objects in the heap dump. Use OQL autocompletion or the Object Inspector to find out about the available fields of an object.

section.title: Accessing Java Bean properties
section.p: Using the @ symbol, OQL accesses attributes of the underlying Java objects used by Memory Analyzer to represent objects in the heap dump. The attributes are resolved via Bean Introspection. Use OQL autocompletion to find the common beans names. The following table lists some commonly used Java attributes.

strow.stentry: IClass of this object. See also classof(object).
the objects in the array (as long values, the addresses of the objects) Access a particular element using get() and convert to an object using OBJECTS.

section.title: Calling Java methods
section.p: Adding ( ) forces OQL to interpret this as a Java method call. The call is executed via reflection. The following table lists some common Java methods on the underlying Java objects used by Memory Analyzer to represent objects in the heap dump.

strow.stentry: result is true if the class has a super class
the result is true if the class is an array type
The address of a snapshot object as a long integer
Java primitive array, Java object array or Java list (returned from reflection)
a value from the array or list

section.title: Array Access
section.p: Memory Analyzer 1.3 or later allows direct array style access of primitive arrays and objects arrays from the snapshot, and Java arrays and Java Lists obtained from reflective method calls. The notation is [index]. The index is a zero-based integer. If the array is null or the index is out of range then the result is null.

Memory Analyzer 1.4 allows array range access as well using the notation [index1:index2] where index1 and index2 are inclusive. If the values are negative then they are treated as indexing from the end of the array, so -1 means the last entry.

section.title: Reading values from primitive arrays
section.codeblock: SELECT s[2] FROM int[] s WHERE (s.@length > 2)
section.p: This method is for Memory Analyzer 1.3 or later.
section.codeblock: SELECT s.getValueAt(2) FROM int[] s WHERE (s.@length > 2)
section.p: This method is for all versions of Memory Analyzer. This reads the value of the element at index 2 from all int[] arrays which have at least 3 elements.

section.title: Reading objects from object arrays
section.codeblock: SELECT s[2] FROM java.lang.Object[] s WHERE (s.@length > 2)
section.p: This method is for Memory Analyzer 1.3 or later. s[2]is an IObject so fields and Java bean properties can be accessed
section.codeblock: SELECT OBJECTS s[2] FROM java.lang.Object[] s
section.p: This method is for Memory Analyzer 1.3 or later. The OBJECTS converts the object to give a tree view rather than table result. We do not need the WHERE clause as out of range accesses return null and the OBJECTS skips nulls.
section.codeblock: SELECT OBJECTS s.@referenceArray.get(2) FROM java.lang.Object[] s WHERE (s.@length > 2)
section.p: This method is for Memory Analyzer 1.1 or later. This reads as a long address the element at index 2 from all Object[] arrays which have at least 3 elements and converts them into objects.
section.codeblock: SELECT OBJECTS s.getReferenceArray(2,1) FROM java.lang.Object[] s WHERE (s.@length > 2)
section.p: This method is for Memory Analyzer 1.1 or later. This reads as an array of long[] 1 element starting at index 2 from all Object[] arrays which have at least 3 elements and converts the contents of those arrays into objects.

section.title: Reading from Java arrays
section.p: This method is for Memory Analyzer 1.3 or later.
section.codeblock: SELECT s.get(2) FROM OBJECTS ${snapshot} s WHERE s.@GCRoots.@length > 2
section.p: This method is for all versions of Memory Analyzer.

section.title: Reading from Java Lists
section.p: This method is for Memory Analyzer 1.3 or later.
This method is for all versions of Memory Analyzer.

strow.stentry: Returns the value of an object, e.g. the content of a String etc.
The objects immediately dominated by the object
the class of the current object
(Experimental in Memory Analyzer 1.4) evaluates the argument and returns it. Could be useful to allow array/method access to the result of a sub-select or expression.
